Authors:
Thilini Chethana, Ruvishika Shehali Jayawardena, Kevin D
Hyde, JiYe Yan, XingHong Li
Title:
Molecular characterization and pathogenicity assessment of
fungal taxa associated with cherry leaf spot disease in Beijing
Keywords:
Colletotrichum, Disease management, morphology,
pathogenicity, Prunus
Abstract:
Cherry leaf spot is one of the most common and devastating
disease of Cherries in the world. The disease causes considerable yield
losses in many cherry growing regions with humid weather conditions. We
surveyed cherry leaf spot in Beijing and collected 67 fungal isolates
from diseased leaves, including Alternaria species, Colletotrichum
species and Didymellaceae species. Multigene phylogenetic analyses
coupled with morphological observations facilitated in identifying the
species isolated from the diseased tissues. According to these analyses,
Alternaria prunicola was concluded as the main pathogen of Cherry leaf
spot. Pathogenicity assays were conducted for six isolates representing
all the isolated species and KochÂ’s postulates were confirmed on three
cultivars of Prunus avium in a greenhouse. These results confirmed the
pathogenicity on cherry leaves as symptoms were reproduced. Significant
variations in the virulence were observed among fungal species on
different cherry cultivars. This work provides evidence that A.
prunicola is the main pathogen of cherry leaf spot in China.
